chapterObjectives: Understand the principles of Newton-Euler dynamics.
Learn how to derive the equations of motion using Newton-Euler formulation.
Apply Newton-Euler dynamics to robotic systems.

content.title: Introduction to Newton-Euler Dynamics
paragraphs: The Newton-Euler formulation is a widely used method for deriving the equations of motion for robotic systems. It combines Newton's second law of motion, which relates force and acceleration, with Euler's equations, which relate torque and angular acceleration.

This method provides a systematic approach for calculating the forces and torques required to achieve a desired motion in a robotic system. It is particularly useful for serial manipulators with multiple degrees of freedom.
The Newton-Euler approach is beneficial for its ability to handle the dynamics of each link in a robot individually, making it a powerful tool for analyzing complex robotic systems.

content.title: Newton's Second Law of Motion
paragraphs: Newton's second law of motion states that the force acting on an object is equal to the mass of the object multiplied by its acceleration: F = ma. This law is fundamental in describing the linear motion of robotic links.

In the context of robotics, Newton's second law is used to describe the linear motion of each link in the robot. The force acting on a link is the sum of the external forces and the inertial forces due to the acceleration of the link.
This law is crucial for understanding how different forces affect the movement of each part of the robot, allowing for precise control and manipulation of robotic arms and other mechanisms.

content.title: Euler's Equations of Motion
paragraphs: Euler's equations of motion describe the rotational dynamics of a rigid body. They relate the torque acting on the body to its angular acceleration and moment of inertia: τ = Iα. These equations are essential for understanding the rotational behavior of robotic links.

In robotics, Euler's equations are used to describe the rotational motion of each link in the robot. The torque acting on a link is the sum of the external torques and the inertial torques due to the angular acceleration of the link.
By combining Euler's equations with Newton's second law, we can develop a comprehensive model of the robot's dynamics, accounting for both linear and rotational motions.

content.title: Forward Recursion
paragraphs: The forward recursion is the first step in the Newton-Euler formulation. It involves calculating the kinematic quantities, such as velocities and accelerations, for each link in the robot, starting from the base and moving towards the end-effector.

During the forward recursion, the known joint positions, velocities, and accelerations are used to compute the linear and angular velocities and accelerations of each link. These kinematic quantities are essential for understanding the motion of each part of the robot.
The forward recursion provides the foundation for the subsequent backward recursion, ensuring that the dynamic analysis is based on accurate kinematic data.

content.title: Backward Recursion
paragraphs: The backward recursion is the second step in the Newton-Euler formulation. It involves calculating the dynamic quantities, such as forces and torques, for each link in the robot, starting from the end-effector and moving towards the base.

During the backward recursion, the kinematic quantities calculated in the forward recursion are used to compute the forces and torques acting on each link. These quantities are then summed to determine the joint torques required to achieve the desired motion.
The backward recursion ensures that the dynamic analysis accounts for all forces and torques in the system, providing a comprehensive understanding of the robot's behavior under various conditions.

content.title: Applications of Newton-Euler Dynamics
paragraphs: The Newton-Euler formulation is used in various robotic applications to design and control robotic systems. In robotic arm manipulation, it is used to calculate the joint torques required to perform precise and stable movements.

In mobile robots, Newton-Euler dynamics is used to control the motion of the robot's wheels or tracks, ensuring stable and efficient navigation. Dynamic control algorithms are used to handle acceleration, deceleration, and turning, allowing the robot to move smoothly and avoid obstacles.

In humanoid robots, Newton-Euler dynamics is used to coordinate the movements of the robot's limbs and maintain balance. This is essential for tasks such as walking, running, and climbing. Dynamic control algorithms ensure that the robot can adapt to different terrains and maintain stability.

In aerospace and underwater robots, Newton-Euler dynamics is used to control the motion of the robot in three-dimensional space, handling complex forces such as lift, drag, and buoyancy. This allows for precise and stable movement in challenging environments.

In the development of exoskeletons and assistive devices, Newton-Euler dynamics helps in designing control systems that can support and enhance human motion. By understanding the dynamics of the human body and the exoskeleton, engineers can create devices that improve mobility and reduce fatigue.

In the field of robotics research, Newton-Euler dynamics is used to develop new algorithms for motion planning, control, and learning. These models provide a foundation for advancing the state of the art in robotics and developing innovative robotic systems.
